outbound.details: Major US City to New York (JFK, LGA, or EWR)
outbound.notes: Prices are estimates for round-trip flights and can vary significantly based on your specific origin city, booking time, and chosen airline. This travel period (post-Thanksgiving) is a high-demand time, so expect higher prices. Booking well in advance (6-12 months out) is highly recommended to secure better rates. Consider flying into any of NYC's three major airports (JFK, LGA, EWR) as all have good public transit connections to Manhattan.

return.details: New York (JFK, LGA, or EWR) to Major US City
return.notes: Return flight pricing typically mirrors the outbound. Look for flexible return times if possible, as morning and late afternoon flights can be busier. Factor in potential luggage fees if applicable.

carRental.type: Mid-size Sedan or Compact SUV (e.g., Toyota Corolla, Nissan Rogue) to accommodate 3 travelers and luggage.
carRental.dailyRate: $70 - $120 (excluding taxes, fees, insurance, and parking costs)
carRental.notes: Renting a car for travel *within* Manhattan is generally not recommended for tourists due to severe traffic congestion, extremely high parking costs ($50-$80+ per day), and limited availability of parking spaces. New York City boasts excellent public transportation. A rental car might be useful for airport transfers with significant luggage or if you plan extensive day trips outside the city to areas not served by public transit (e.g., Upstate New York, Long Island wineries). If you choose to rent, consider picking up the car at an airport location rather than in Manhattan to save on city surcharges.

options: MTA Subway & Bus: This is the most efficient, cost-effective, and popular way to get around NYC. The network is extensive, operating 24/7. OMNY (tap-to-pay with your contactless credit/debit card or smartphone/smartwatch) is the easiest payment method ($2.90 per ride).
7-Day Unlimited Ride MetroCard/OMNY: If you plan to use transit frequently, a 7-day unlimited pass ($34 including a new card fee) can be a good value.
Long Island Rail Road (LIRR) / Metro-North Railroad: Commuter rail lines for travel to outer boroughs or surrounding suburbs.
publicTransit.estimatedCostFor3Travelers: $102 (for three 7-day unlimited passes) or approximately $2.90 per ride via OMNY.

rideSharing.notes: Widely available throughout the city. Useful for late-night travel, specific destinations not easily reached by subway, or when carrying heavy luggage. Prices can fluctuate significantly based on demand (surge pricing) and distance. Airport transfers can be expensive (e.g., $60-$100+ from JFK/LGA to Manhattan).

taxis.notes: Readily available, especially in Manhattan. Metered fares, with surcharges for peak hours, late night, and airport trips. Can be a good option for shorter distances or when ride-share pricing is high. Expect cash tolls for bridges/tunnels.

airportTransfers.JFK: AirTrain to Jamaica Station (for LIRR or E/J/Z subway lines) or Howard Beach (for A subway line). Total cost approximately $8.25 (AirTrain) + $2.90 (subway) per person. Journey time ~60-90 minutes to Manhattan.
airportTransfers.LGA: MTA M60-SBS bus to subway lines (125th St in Manhattan) or Q70-SBS bus to subway lines (Jackson Hts/Roosevelt Ave in Queens). Cost $2.90 per person. Journey time ~45-75 minutes to Manhattan.
airportTransfers.EWR: AirTrain to Newark Liberty International Airport Station, then NJ Transit or Amtrak train to Penn Station (NYC). Cost ~$15-$20 per person. Journey time ~45-60 minutes to Manhattan.

localTransportation.notes: For most sightseeing and movement within Manhattan, the subway offers the best combination of speed, cost, and coverage. Budget approximately $100-$300 for local transportation, including public transit passes and a few ride-shares/taxis for convenience.

accommodation.description: Immerse yourselves in the pulse of New York City at SIXTY LES, a sophisticated boutique hotel perfectly situated in the vibrant Lower East Side. This neighborhood is a playground for urban adventurers, offering a rich tapestry of history, street art, diverse culinary experiences, and unique boutiques to explore by day. As night falls, the area transforms into a premier destination for nightlife, with an abundance of trendy bars, live music venues, and clubs just steps away. The hotel itself boasts a sleek, art-centric design, a lively lounge, and a rooftop bar (with a seasonal pool) offering spectacular city panoramas. It's the ideal choice for three travelers seeking both dynamic urban exploration and unforgettable evening entertainment.

restaurants.name: Katz's Delicatessen
restaurants.specialty: An iconic New York institution famous for its massive, hand-carved pastrami and corned beef sandwiches. A truly authentic and bustling NYC experience.

restaurants.name: Joe's Shanghai (Midtown or Chinatown)
restaurants.specialty: World-renowned for its delicate and flavorful soup dumplings (xiao long bao), a culinary adventure perfect for sharing.
mustTry: Crab Meat & Pork Steamed Buns (Soup Dumplings)

restaurants.name: Carbone
restaurants.specialty: An upscale, retro-glamorous take on classic Italian-American 'red-sauce' dishes, known for its lively atmosphere and celebrity sightings. Reservations are essential and an adventure to secure.

restaurants.name: Prince Street Pizza
restaurants.specialty: A Soho favorite famous for its thick-crusted, crispy-edged Sicilian 'Soho Square' slices, especially the spicy spring version with cupped pepperoni. Expect a line, but it's worth the adventure!

restaurants.name: Please Don't Tell (PDT)
restaurants.specialty: A 'hidden' speakeasy cocktail bar accessed through a vintage phone booth inside Crif Dogs. Known for its inventive craft cocktails and gourmet hot dogs, perfect for a unique nightlife experience.
mustTry: Any of their seasonal craft cocktails (ask the mixologist)
The 'Waffler' (hot dog from Crif Dogs next door)

activities.morning: Arrive in New York City, check into accommodation, and settle in. Take a casual stroll around your hotel's vicinity or Bryant Park to get oriented.
activities.afternoon: Explore the modern architectural wonders of Hudson Yards. Walk a section of The High Line elevated park for unique city views.
activities.evening: Enjoy an early dinner at Joe's Shanghai (Midtown) for their famous soup dumplings. Afterwards, head to the Edge Observation Deck for a breathtaking sunset and night view of the Manhattan skyline.

activities.morning: Take the scenic ferry from Lower Manhattan to Governors Island. Spend the morning exploring the island's parks, historic sites, and enjoying panoramic views of the Statue of Liberty and the city skyline. Consider renting a bike.
activities.afternoon: Return to Lower Manhattan. Explore the historic Financial District, including Wall Street, the New York Stock Exchange, and the Charging Bull. Walk through Battery Park.
activities.evening: Wander the charming, historic streets of Greenwich Village. Enjoy dinner at a local restaurant in the Village. Afterwards, experience the unique speakeasy atmosphere and craft cocktails at Please Don't Tell (PDT) in the East Village/Lower East Side area.

activities.morning: Immerse yourself in the trendy boutiques, art galleries, and distinctive architecture of SoHo. Enjoy some window shopping and people-watching.
activities.afternoon: Grab a delicious and iconic slice (or two) of pizza for lunch at Prince Street Pizza, famous for its Soho Square slices. Continue exploring the SoHo/NoHo area, perhaps strolling towards Washington Square Park.
activities.evening: Enjoy a pre-theater dinner at Joe's Shanghai (Midtown location) for convenience. Afterwards, experience the magic of a live Broadway Show in the iconic Theater District.

activities.morning: Embark on an adventure to Brooklyn's Coney Island (seasonal, typically Spring to Fall). Spend the morning enjoying the classic amusement park rides at Luna Park, the boardwalk, and the beach atmosphere.
activities.afternoon: Continue to soak in the Coney Island experience. Enjoy classic boardwalk snacks like hot dogs and funnel cake for lunch. Relax by the beach or try more rides.
activities.evening: Travel back towards North Brooklyn (e.g., Williamsburg). Enjoy dinner at a local Williamsburg restaurant. Conclude your day with drinks and stunning views of the Manhattan skyline from one of Brooklyn's renowned Rooftop Bars (e.g., Westlight or The William Vale).

activities.morning: Start early for a full-day trip to Bear Mountain State Park. Travel by bus or rental car (approx. 1.5-2 hours each way). Enjoy a scenic hike to Perkins Memorial Tower for breathtaking panoramic views of the Hudson River Valley.
activities.afternoon: Continue to explore the natural beauty of Bear Mountain. Visit Hessian Lake, walk some of the trails, or simply relax and enjoy the fresh air. Pack a lunch or grab a bite at the park's limited concessions.
activities.evening: Return to New York City after a day in nature. Indulge in a hearty, authentic New York meal at Katz's Delicatessen, famous for its pastrami and corned beef sandwiches, to refuel.

activities.morning: Explore the vibrant and historic Lower East Side. Discover its rich history, unique street art, independent boutiques, and charming cafes.
activities.afternoon: Enjoy a leisurely late lunch or revisit Katz's Delicatessen for a full experience if you didn't have enough time the previous night. Alternatively, explore more of the East Village or head towards the West Village.
activities.evening: For a memorable farewell dinner, indulge in an upscale Italian-American experience at Carbone in the West Village. Be sure to secure reservations well in advance for this sought-after spot. Afterwards, enjoy a final stroll or a quiet drink.

activities.morning: Enjoy a relaxed New York City brunch or revisit a favorite coffee spot for a final taste of the city. Do some last-minute souvenir shopping.
activities.afternoon: Depending on your flight schedule, take a final walk through a charming neighborhood like Washington Square Park or grab a casual last meal.
activities.evening: Depart from New York City, carrying memories of your unforgettable 7-day adventure.

localTips: Master the Subway: Purchase a MetroCard for seamless travel; it's the fastest and most cost-effective way to navigate the city. Avoid driving if possible.
Wear Comfortable Shoes: You'll be doing a lot of walking, often more than you expect. Prioritize comfortable footwear over fashion.
Embrace Tipping Culture: Tipping 15-20% at restaurants, bars, and for services like taxis or hotel porters is standard and expected.
Book Popular Attractions in Advance: For places like the Empire State Building, Statue of Liberty, or Broadway shows, buy tickets online ahead of time to save time and secure your spot.
Always Be Aware of Your Surroundings: While generally safe, maintain street smarts, especially in crowded areas or late at night. Keep valuables secure.
Explore Beyond Midtown: Venture into neighborhoods like the West Village, Dumbo, or Astoria for a more local feel, unique shops, and diverse culinary experiences.
Walk with Purpose: New Yorkers walk fast and often. Avoid stopping suddenly in the middle of a sidewalk; step aside if you need to consult a map or group.
